elements.content: A three-dimensional (3D) anionic Cd-MOF, namely, (Me2NH2)2­[Cd­(PTC)]­·2H2O, assembled by a Cd­(II) salt and a planar aromatic core ligand containing tetracarboxylate groups (H4PTC = pyrene-1,3,6,8-tetracarboxylic acid), has been successfully constructed through a solvothermal method. In the structure of the fabricated Cd-PTC, each Cd­(II) center links four carboxyl groups, and each PTC4– ligand connects four Cd­(II) ions through the deprotonated carboxylate groups in bidentate chelating style, generating a 3D network with one-dimensional rhombic channels. This topology was considered to be a 3D (4,4)-connected pts net. Gas sorption measurements reveal that desolvated Cd-PTC has a strong interaction with CO2 and displays highly selective CO2 capture between the mixed gases CO2/CH4 and CO2/N2. Meanwhile, luminescent studies reveal that Cd-PTC can detect nitroaromatic explosives, especially exhibiting significant sensitivity for 2,4,6-trinitrophenol in DMF solvent.
elements.clean_text: A three-dimensional (3D) anionic Cd-MOF, namely, (Me2NH2)2[Cd(PTC)]⋅2H2O, assembled by a Cd(II) salt and a planar aromatic core ligand containing tetracarboxylate groups (H4PTC = pyrene-1,3,6,8-tetracarboxylic acid), has been successfully constructed through a solvothermal method. In the structure of the fabricated Cd-PTC, each Cd(II) center links four carboxyl groups, and each PTC4- ligand connects four Cd(II) ions through the deprotonated carboxylate groups in bidentate chelating style, generating a 3D network with one-dimensional rhombic channels. This topology was considered to be a 3D (4,4)-connected pts net. Gas sorption measurements reveal that desolvated Cd-PTC has a strong interaction with CO2 and displays highly selective CO2 capture between the mixed gases CO2/CH4 and CO2/N2. Meanwhile, luminescent studies reveal that Cd-PTC can detect nitroaromatic explosives, especially exhibiting significant sensitivity for 2,4,6-trinitrophenol in DMF solvent.

elements.content: We report a pyrene-based anionic Cd-metal−organic framework with a one-dimensional channel, which displays an interesting selective adsorption of CO2 over N2 and CH4, together with an important sensor to detect nitroaromatic explosives.
elements.clean_text: We report a pyrene-based anionic Cd-metal-organic framework with a one-dimensional channel, which displays an interesting selective adsorption of CO2 over N2 and CH4, together with an important sensor to detect nitroaromatic explosives.

elements.content: Metal–organic frameworks (MOFs), as an advanced functional solid material, constructed from metal ions and organic linkers, have attracted tremendous interest on account of their chemical tenability, large surface area, and high porosity, along with the diverse applications in gas separation, catalysis, energy storage devices, luminescence, and so on. Especially, much research has focused on MOFs construction with selective CO2 capture due to the threat of global warming from CO2 emission. Many research strategies have been adopted in order to improve CO2 uptake capacity and selectivity, such as selecting suitable ligands, rationally modifying pores with N-rich or polarizing groups, increasing the interpenetrated structure by extending flexibility of organic ligand, and altering coordination modes of metal ions during the construction of MOFs. Apparently, it is essential to balance high capacity and selectivity for CO2 since some strategies may result in a decrease in surface area and CO2 absorption capacity.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs), as an advanced functional solid material, constructed from metal ions and organic linkers, have attracted tremendous interest on account of their chemical tenability, large surface area, and high porosity, along with the diverse applications in gas separation, catalysis, energy storage devices, luminescence, and so on. Especially, much research has focused on MOFs construction with selective CO2 capture due to the threat of global warming from CO2 emission. Many research strategies have been adopted in order to improve CO2 uptake capacity and selectivity, such as selecting suitable ligands, rationally modifying pores with N-rich or polarizing groups, increasing the interpenetrated structure by extending flexibility of organic ligand, and altering coordination modes of metal ions during the construction of MOFs. Apparently, it is essential to balance high capacity and selectivity for CO2 since some strategies may result in a decrease in surface area and CO2 absorption capacity.

elements.content: On the other hand, MOFs could be used as fluorescence sensors for small organic molecules, inorganic anions, and metal anions. Compared with the traditional organic or inorganic fluorescent sensing materials, MOFs have the following advantages: (1) MOFs can realize enrichment of porous material, thereby reducing the detection limit; and (2) rational design of ligands can improve the specificity of recognition the target object detection. We have been working on the construction of MOFs, which have been utilized in energy storage, chemical sensors, and devices. As continuous work, herein, we report a new pyrene-based anionic Cd-based MOF, (Me2NH2)2­[Cd­(PTC)]­·2H2O, which was assembled from a large delocalized tetracarbxylate ligand, namely, pyrene-1,3,6,8-tetracarboxylic acid. Interestingly, this Cd-PTC shows selective CO2 uptake and cooperative highly sensitive detection of nitroaromatic explosives.
elements.clean_text: On the other hand, MOFs could be used as fluorescence sensors for small organic molecules, inorganic anions, and metal anions. Compared with the traditional organic or inorganic fluorescent sensing materials, MOFs have the following advantages: (1) MOFs can realize enrichment of porous material, thereby reducing the detection limit; and (2) rational design of ligands can improve the specificity of recognition the target object detection. We have been working on the construction of MOFs, which have been utilized in energy storage, chemical sensors, and devices. As continuous work, herein, we report a new pyrene-based anionic Cd-based MOF, (Me2NH2)2[Cd(PTC)]⋅2H2O, which was assembled from a large delocalized tetracarbxylate ligand, namely, pyrene-1,3,6,8-tetracarboxylic acid. Interestingly, this Cd-PTC shows selective CO2 uptake and cooperative highly sensitive detection of nitroaromatic explosives.

elements.content: All commercially received solvents and reagents were directly used. Elemental analysis was recorded on a PerkinElmer 240 elemental analyzer. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was performed on a Netzsch Thermo Microbalance TG 209 F3 Tarsus under nitrogen atmosphere. The purity phase was confirmed by powder X-ray powder diffraction (PXRD) patterns on a Bruker D8 Advance diffractometer. Porous property was determined on a Quantachrome Autosorb-iQ-MP gas sorption analyzer. Emission and excitation spectra were measured by a Hitachi F-2500 and Edinburgh-FLS-920 spectrometer.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

General Information

All commercially received solvents and reagents were directly used. Elemental analysis was recorded on a PerkinElmer 240 elemental analyzer. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was performed on a Netzsch Thermo Microbalance TG 209 F3 Tarsus under nitrogen atmosphere. The purity phase was confirmed by powder X-ray powder diffraction (PXRD) patterns on a Bruker D8 Advance diffractometer. Porous property was determined on a Quantachrome Autosorb-iQ-MP gas sorption analyzer. Emission and excitation spectra were measured by a Hitachi F-2500 and Edinburgh-FLS-920 spectrometer.

elements.content: A mixture of H4PTC (0.1 mmol, 38 mg), Cd­(NO3)2·4H2O (0.1 mmol, 30 mg), HNO3(60 μL), DMF (4 mL), and H2O (2 mL) was placed in a 10 mL screw-capped vial and heated at 100 °C for 3 days. Then the mixture was allowed to cool to ambient temperature. Block crystals were collected, washed with DMF for twice, subsequently dried in air. Yield: 43% (based on H2PTC ligand). Elemental analysis for Cd-PTC (C24H26N2O10Cd): calculated (%): C, 46.88; H, 4.26; N, 4.56; found (%): C, 46.69; H, 4.20; N, 4.58.
elements.clean_text:
Preparation of (Me2NH2)2[Cd(PTC)]⋅2H2O

A mixture of H4PTC (0.1 mmol, 38 mg), Cd(NO3)2⋅4H2O (0.1 mmol, 30 mg), HNO3(60 μL), DMF (4 mL), and H2O (2 mL) was placed in a 10 mL screw-capped vial and heated at 100 °C for 3 days. Then the mixture was allowed to cool to ambient temperature. Block crystals were collected, washed with DMF for twice, subsequently dried in air. Yield: 43% (based on H2PTC ligand). Elemental analysis for Cd-PTC (C24H26N2O10Cd): calculated (%): C, 46.88; H, 4.26; N, 4.56; found (%): C, 46.69; H, 4.20; N, 4.58.

elements.content: Bruker APEX II diffractometer (Mo–Kα radiation, λ = 0.71073 Å) was applied to collect all the diffraction data. A difference vectors method was used to perform indexing. Full-matrix least-squares on F 2 (SHELXL-2014) was used to solve and refine the structure through direct methods. Highly disordered [Me2NH2]+ cations and solvent molecules in the structure were removed using the SQUEEZE routine of PLATON. Then the final structure was further refined by using the generating data from SQUEEZE routine. Crystallographic data and selected bond lengths are summarized in Table S1 and Table S2.
elements.clean_text:
X-ray Structure Determination

Bruker APEX II diffractometer (Mo-Kα radiation, λ = 0.71073 Å) was applied to collect all the diffraction data. A difference vectors method was used to perform indexing. Full-matrix least-squares on F 2 (SHELXL-2014) was used to solve and refine the structure through direct methods. Highly disordered [Me2NH2]+ cations and solvent molecules in the structure were removed using the SQUEEZE routine of PLATON. Then the final structure was further refined by using the generating data from SQUEEZE routine. Crystallographic data and selected bond lengths are summarized in Table S1 and Table S2.

elements.content: H4PTC ligand was obtained through previously reported methods. Reaction of H4PTC with Cd­(NO3)2­·4H2O generated Cd-PTC crystals. The formula was verified through elemental analysis and TGA data to be (Me2NH2)2­[Cd­(PTC)]­·2H2O. Structural analysis showed that Cd-PTC crystallized in monoclinic space group C2/c. Each Cd2+ metal center coordinated four bidentate chelating carboxylate groups from four discrete ligands (a), while each PTC4– ligand connected four Cd2+ ions (b), thus forming a novel three-dimensional (3D) anionic MOF along the [100] direction (c). As shown in d,e, this framework possessed 1D rhombic channels with size of 3.5 × 3.6 Å2 along the [001] direction. The calculated solvent accessible volume was 1580.6 Å3 (unit cell volume of 2953.3 Å3), and the porosity was as high as 53.5% by using PLATON. To better understand the intrinsic structure, TOPOS 4.0 program was applied to conduct the topology analysis of Cd-PTC. Each ligand and each Cd2+ ion serve as 4-connected node, respectively, and thus the whole framework could be regarded as binodal (4,4)-connected pts topology with a point symbol of (42·84) (f).
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

H4PTC ligand was obtained through previously reported methods. Reaction of H4PTC with Cd(NO3)2⋅4H2O generated Cd-PTC crystals. The formula was verified through elemental analysis and TGA data to be (Me2NH2)2[Cd(PTC)]⋅2H2O. Structural analysis showed that Cd-PTC crystallized in monoclinic space group C2/c. Each Cd2+ metal center coordinated four bidentate chelating carboxylate groups from four discrete ligands (a), while each PTC4- ligand connected four Cd2+ ions (b), thus forming a novel three-dimensional (3D) anionic MOF along the [100] direction (c). As shown in d,e, this framework possessed 1D rhombic channels with size of 3.5 × 3.6 Å2 along the [001] direction. The calculated solvent accessible volume was 1580.6 Å3 (unit cell volume of 2953.3 Å3), and the porosity was as high as 53.5% by using PLATON. To better understand the intrinsic structure, TOPOS 4.0 program was applied to conduct the topology analysis of Cd-PTC. Each ligand and each Cd2+ ion serve as 4-connected node, respectively, and thus the whole framework could be regarded as binodal (4,4)-connected pts topology with a point symbol of (42⋅84) (f).

elements.content: (a) Coordination environment of Cd2+ ion. Symmetry code: A: 1 – x, y, 0.5 – z; B: 0.5 – x, 0.5 + y, 0.5 – z; C: 0.5 + x, 0.5 + y, z. (b) Coordination style of PTC4– ligand. (c) and (d) Polyhedral view of 3D framework from [100] and [001] directions, respectively. (e) Space-filling of the porous 3D framework with 1D rhombic channel. (f) (4,4)-connected pts topology.
elements.clean_text: 1  (a) Coordination environment of Cd2+ ion. Symmetry code: A: 1 - x, y, 0.5 - z; B: 0.5 - x, 0.5 + y, 0.5 - z; C: 0.5 + x, 0.5 + y, z. (b) Coordination style of PTC4- ligand. (c) and (d) Polyhedral view of 3D framework from [100] and [001] directions, respectively. (e) Space-filling of the porous 3D framework with 1D rhombic channel. (f) (4,4)-connected pts topology.

elements.content: Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) of as-prepared Cd-PTC and desolvated Cd-PTC are shown in Figure S1. As-prepared Cd-PTC showed a first weight loss of 5.39%, corresponding to two free water molecules (calcd 5.85%). Subsequently, the whole framework stated to collapse above the temperature of 250 °C. PXRD is an effective method to investigate the crystalline structure of the synthesized samples. As presented in Figure S2, phase purity could be confirmed by the well-matched diffraction peaks between the as-prepared products and the simulated one.
elements.clean_text: Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) of as-prepared Cd-PTC and desolvated Cd-PTC are shown in Figure S1. As-prepared Cd-PTC showed a first weight loss of 5.39%, corresponding to two free water molecules (calcd 5.85%). Subsequently, the whole framework stated to collapse above the temperature of 250 °C. PXRD is an effective method to investigate the crystalline structure of the synthesized samples. As presented in Figure S2, phase purity could be confirmed by the well-matched diffraction peaks between the as-prepared products and the simulated one.

elements.content: Considering the pore properties, gas sorption experiments were performed. To obtain dehydrated phase Cd-PTC, as-prepared samples were heated under a vacuum at 80 °C for 5 h to remove all guest H2O molecules. TGA and PXRD patterns of the dehydrated phase further confirmed that the preservation of its crystallinity and the whole framework maintained intact structure (Figures S1 and S2). Nitrogen adsorption/desorption isotherm at 77 K showed the N2 uptake reached 302.4 cm3 g–1 and exhibited a typical type-I curve with an abrupt increase at the beginning (Figure S3), indicating the microporous characteristics. Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) surface area is 965 m2 g–1, while the total pore volume was found to be 0.57 cm3 g–1.
elements.clean_text: Considering the pore properties, gas sorption experiments were performed. To obtain dehydrated phase Cd-PTC, as-prepared samples were heated under a vacuum at 80 °C for 5 h to remove all guest H2O molecules. TGA and PXRD patterns of the dehydrated phase further confirmed that the preservation of its crystallinity and the whole framework maintained intact structure (Figures S1 and S2). Nitrogen adsorption/desorption isotherm at 77 K showed the N2 uptake reached 302.4 cm3 g-1 and exhibited a typical type-I curve with an abrupt increase at the beginning (Figure S3), indicating the microporous characteristics. Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) surface area is 965 m2 g-1, while the total pore volume was found to be 0.57 cm3 g-1.

elements.content: To better evaluate the porosity, different gas sorption curves were taken on, respectively. Obviously, adsorption isotherms of CO2 possess good uptake of 80 cm3 g–1 (273 K) and 58 cm3 g–1(298 K), respectively (a). However, adsorption capacities of N2 and CH4 are quite minimal at the corresponding temperature. Apparently, it displayed a selective adsorption for CO2 over CH4 and N2. This phenomenon could be ascribed to significant CO2 quadrupole moment with a value of −1.4 × 10–39 cm2, generating specific interactions with host frameworks. To better test the sorption selectivity, we applied ideal adsorption solution theory to calculate separation selectivity of CO2 versus N2 or CH4 (volume ratios, 15/85 and 50/50) at ambient pressure up to 100 kPa. As presented in b, the selectivity of CO2/N2 gradually decreased from 175 to 106 (V/V, 15/85). As for CO2/CH4, the selectivity was 31 to 19 (V/V, 50/50). These results indicated that the Cd-PTC framework has strong affinity toward CO2 compared with N2 and CH4.
elements.clean_text: To better evaluate the porosity, different gas sorption curves were taken on, respectively. Obviously, adsorption isotherms of CO2 possess good uptake of 80 cm3 g-1 (273 K) and 58 cm3 g-1(298 K), respectively (a). However, adsorption capacities of N2 and CH4 are quite minimal at the corresponding temperature. Apparently, it displayed a selective adsorption for CO2 over CH4 and N2. This phenomenon could be ascribed to significant CO2 quadrupole moment with a value of -1.4 × 10-39 cm2, generating specific interactions with host frameworks. To better test the sorption selectivity, we applied ideal adsorption solution theory to calculate separation selectivity of CO2 versus N2 or CH4 (volume ratios, 15/85 and 50/50) at ambient pressure up to 100 kPa. As presented in b, the selectivity of CO2/N2 gradually decreased from 175 to 106 (V/V, 15/85). As for CO2/CH4, the selectivity was 31 to 19 (V/V, 50/50). These results indicated that the Cd-PTC framework has strong affinity toward CO2 compared with N2 and CH4.

elements.content: (a) Gas adsorption isotherms. (b) Selectivity of CO2/N2 (V/V, 15/85) and CO2/CH4 (V/V, 50/50) mixed gases calculated by the IAST method. (c) and (d) Column breakthrough experiments for mixed gases CO2/N2 (V/V, 15/85) and CO2/CH4 (V/V, 50/50) at 298 K, respectively.
elements.clean_text: 2  (a) Gas adsorption isotherms. (b) Selectivity of CO2/N2 (V/V, 15/85) and CO2/CH4 (V/V, 50/50) mixed gases calculated by the IAST method. (c) and (d) Column breakthrough experiments for mixed gases CO2/N2 (V/V, 15/85) and CO2/CH4 (V/V, 50/50) at 298 K, respectively.

elements.content: To further determinate real separation and purification properties, we carried out the dynamic column breakthrough experiments. Thus, mixed gases of CO2/N2 (V/V, 15/85) flowed over a packed bed of Cd-PTC samples at 298 K. Apparently, CO2 could be successfully separated from the mixture with dynamic CO2 uptake of 0.78 mmol g–1, which is compatible to the well-known HKUST-1 (0.45 mmol g–1) and IRMOF-74 (8 mmol g–1). As for CO2/CH4 (V/V, 50/50), at a shorter dimensionless time, the breakthrough could be observed on account of a relatively lower separation ratio of the mixed gases.
elements.clean_text: To further determinate real separation and purification properties, we carried out the dynamic column breakthrough experiments. Thus, mixed gases of CO2/N2 (V/V, 15/85) flowed over a packed bed of Cd-PTC samples at 298 K. Apparently, CO2 could be successfully separated from the mixture with dynamic CO2 uptake of 0.78 mmol g-1, which is compatible to the well-known HKUST-1 (0.45 mmol g-1) and IRMOF-74 (8 mmol g-1). As for CO2/CH4 (V/V, 50/50), at a shorter dimensionless time, the breakthrough could be observed on account of a relatively lower separation ratio of the mixed gases.

elements.content: According to the previous studies, a large π-conjugated pyrene core could be applied as efficient chromophores to sensitize metal centers through energy transfer, which inspired us to detect the fluorescent properties of Cd-PTC. Therefore, the emission spectra of organic ligand and Cd-PTC were collected at ambient temperature in DMF. As depicted in , Cd-PTC exhibited a broad emission peak at 428 nm (λex = 363 nm). Obviously, a red-shift was observed in comparison with an emission peak of 374 nm for organic ligand, suggesting efficient ligand-to-metal charge transfer. On the other hand, the fluorescent intensity Cd-PTC is stronger than the ligand, indicating that the incorporation of Cd­(II) ion can effectively reduce the energy loss. The enhanced fluorescent properties proved it to be an outstanding candidate for blue fluorescent materials.
elements.clean_text: According to the previous studies, a large π-conjugated pyrene core could be applied as efficient chromophores to sensitize metal centers through energy transfer, which inspired us to detect the fluorescent properties of Cd-PTC. Therefore, the emission spectra of organic ligand and Cd-PTC were collected at ambient temperature in DMF. As depicted in , Cd-PTC exhibited a broad emission peak at 428 nm (λex = 363 nm). Obviously, a red-shift was observed in comparison with an emission peak of 374 nm for organic ligand, suggesting efficient ligand-to-metal charge transfer. On the other hand, the fluorescent intensity Cd-PTC is stronger than the ligand, indicating that the incorporation of Cd(II) ion can effectively reduce the energy loss. The enhanced fluorescent properties proved it to be an outstanding candidate for blue fluorescent materials.

elements.content: Emission spectra for free H4PTC ligands and Cd-PTC.
elements.clean_text: 3  Emission spectra for free H4PTC ligands and Cd-PTC.

elements.content: To further explore the fluorescent sensing ability of Cd-PTC, the bulk of the crystal solid was soaked in a variety of solvents (DMF, MeOH, EtOH, 1,4-dioxane, DMAc, MeCN, THF, acetone, chloroform, and dichloromethane) for 1 day and further ultrasonicated for 20 min. Then the resulting suspension was filtered for fluorescent measurements. The emission spectra in Figure S4 reveal that common organic solvents have no significant influence on the fluorescence intensity. Additionally, we further investigated the fluorescence response of different aromatic compounds. It was found that Cd-PTC had a significant fluorescence quenching effect toward nitrobenzene (a). This phenomenon mainly results from the electron transfer behavior between the host–guest interactions from the framework to the nitrobenzene with the electron-withdrawing group. To further investigate the fluorescence quenching effect, we studied nitroaromatic explosives (b), including 4-nitrotoluene (NT), nitrobenzene (NB), 4-nitroaniline (NA), 2,4,6-trinitrophenol (TNP), 4-nitrophenol (NP), and 1,4-dinitrobenzene (DNB). The observed results show that the quenching effect was TNP > DNB > NP> NA > NT > NB. Obviously, a highly effective selectivity for TNP was detected from the observed data. The phenomenon was mainly ascribed to the OH– and three NO3 – groups from TNP. With the increasing of the electrodeficient groups, electron transfers become easier, and more efficient fluorescence quenching was detected. To further monitor the sensitivity of TNP in DMF, Cd-PTC samples were dispersed into DMF solution to form a suspension. To this suspension 1 mM TNP solution was added gradually. Obviously, fluorescence intensity continuously quenched with gradual addition of TNP solution (c). The Stern–Volmer equation (I 0/I = K sv[M] + 1) was used to calculate and analyze fluorescence quenching efficiency, where K sv represents quenching constant. At low concentrations, the Stern–Volmer plot was almost linear with a quenching constant of 6.89 mM–1 (d). Subsequently, it deviated from linearity with upward bending when the concentrations increased. The linear nature of the SV curve may be attributed to molecular packing interaction or π-electron-rich transfer process. Moreover, the detection limit (D) was found to be 0.433 mM by applying equation D = 3σ/K sv, where σ corresponds to standard deviation, indicating good sensing property toward TNP. Additionally, PXRD patterns after CO2 capture and TNP sensor and CO2 capture were measured, demonstrating the integrity of the frameworks and good stability (Figure S5).
elements.clean_text: To further explore the fluorescent sensing ability of Cd-PTC, the bulk of the crystal solid was soaked in a variety of solvents (DMF, MeOH, EtOH, 1,4-dioxane, DMAc, MeCN, THF, acetone, chloroform, and dichloromethane) for 1 day and further ultrasonicated for 20 min. Then the resulting suspension was filtered for fluorescent measurements. The emission spectra in Figure S4 reveal that common organic solvents have no significant influence on the fluorescence intensity. Additionally, we further investigated the fluorescence response of different aromatic compounds. It was found that Cd-PTC had a significant fluorescence quenching effect toward nitrobenzene (a). This phenomenon mainly results from the electron transfer behavior between the host-guest interactions from the framework to the nitrobenzene with the electron-withdrawing group. To further investigate the fluorescence quenching effect, we studied nitroaromatic explosives (b), including 4-nitrotoluene (NT), nitrobenzene (NB), 4-nitroaniline (NA), 2,4,6-trinitrophenol (TNP), 4-nitrophenol (NP), and 1,4-dinitrobenzene (DNB). The observed results show that the quenching effect was TNP > DNB > NP> NA > NT > NB. Obviously, a highly effective selectivity for TNP was detected from the observed data. The phenomenon was mainly ascribed to the OH- and three NO3 - groups from TNP. With the increasing of the electrodeficient groups, electron transfers become easier, and more efficient fluorescence quenching was detected. To further monitor the sensitivity of TNP in DMF, Cd-PTC samples were dispersed into DMF solution to form a suspension. To this suspension 1 mM TNP solution was added gradually. Obviously, fluorescence intensity continuously quenched with gradual addition of TNP solution (c). The Stern-Volmer equation (I 0/I = K sv[M] + 1) was used to calculate and analyze fluorescence quenching efficiency, where K sv represents quenching constant. At low concentrations, the Stern-Volmer plot was almost linear with a quenching constant of 6.89 mM-1 (d). Subsequently, it deviated from linearity with upward bending when the concentrations increased. The linear nature of the SV curve may be attributed to molecular packing interaction or π-electron-rich transfer process. Moreover, the detection limit (D) was found to be 0.433 mM by applying equation D = 3σ/K sv, where σ corresponds to standard deviation, indicating good sensing property toward TNP. Additionally, PXRD patterns after CO2 capture and TNP sensor and CO2 capture were measured, demonstrating the integrity of the frameworks and good stability (Figure S5).

elements.content: (a) Emission spectra of Cd-PTC with different aromatic compounds in DMF, respectively. (b) Relations between fluorescent intensities and concentrations for TNP. (c) Degree of fluorescence quenching with different nitrobenzene derivatives. (d) Stern–Volmer plots for Cd-PTC with TNP. Inset is the low concentration regions at 298 K, respectively.

(c) Degree of fluorescence quenching with different nitrobenzene derivatives. (d) Stern-Volmer plots for Cd-PTC with TNP. Inset is the low concentration regions at 298 K, respectively.

elements.content: In summary, a new 3D anionic MOF (Cd-PTC) with a (4,4)-connected pts net topology, constructed by a pyrene-based tetracarboxylate ligand (H4PTC) has been investigated. Due to the existence of the porous property and large conjugated core in the framework, Cd-PTC exhibits a highly selective CO2 adsorption together with a fluorescent sensing for detecting nitroaromatic explosives. We anticipate that this work can provide a strategy to synthesize multifunctional materials with potential for separation and purification of CO2 gas and sensor for nitroaromatic explosives.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

In summary, a new 3D anionic MOF (Cd-PTC) with a (4,4)-connected pts net topology, constructed by a pyrene-based tetracarboxylate ligand (H4PTC) has been investigated. Due to the existence of the porous property and large conjugated core in the framework, Cd-PTC exhibits a highly selective CO2 adsorption together with a fluorescent sensing for detecting nitroaromatic explosives. We anticipate that this work can provide a strategy to synthesize multifunctional materials with potential for separation and purification of CO2 gas and sensor for nitroaromatic explosives.

cln_elements.clean_text:
Preparation of (Me2NH2)2[Cd(PTC)]⋅2H2O

A mixture of H4PTC (0.1 mmol, 38 mg), Cd(NO3)2⋅4H2O (0.1 mmol, 30 mg), HNO3(60 μL), DMF (4 mL), and H2O (2 mL) was placed in a 10 mL screw-capped vial and heated at 100 °C for 3 days. Then the mixture was allowed to cool to ambient temperature. Block crystals were collected, washed with DMF for twice, subsequently dried in air. Yield: 43% (based on H2PTC ligand). Elemental analysis for Cd-PTC (C24H26N2O10Cd): calculated (%): C, 46.88; H, 4.26; N, 4.56; found (%): C, 46.69; H, 4.20; N, 4.58.

cln_elements.content:
H4PTC ligand was obtained through previously reported methods. Reaction of H4PTC with Cd­(NO3)2­·4H2O generated Cd-PTC crystals. The formula was verified through elemental analysis and TGA data to be (Me2NH2)2­[Cd­(PTC)]­·2H2O. Structural analysis showed that Cd-PTC crystallized in monoclinic space group C2/c. Each Cd2+ metal center coordinated four bidentate chelating carboxylate groups from four discrete ligands (a), while each PTC4– ligand connected four Cd2+ ions (b), thus forming a novel three-dimensional (3D) anionic MOF along the [100] direction (c). As shown in d,e, this framework possessed 1D rhombic channels with size of 3.5 × 3.6 Å2 along the [001] direction. The calculated solvent accessible volume was 1580.6 Å3 (unit cell volume of 2953.3 Å3), and the porosity was as high as 53.5% by using PLATON. To better understand the intrinsic structure, TOPOS 4.0 program was applied to conduct the topology analysis of Cd-PTC. Each ligand and each Cd2+ ion serve as 4-connected node, respectively, and thus the whole framework could be regarded as binodal (4,4)-connected pts topology with a point symbol of (42·84) (f).

Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) of as-prepared Cd-PTC and desolvated Cd-PTC are shown in Figure S1. As-prepared Cd-PTC showed a first weight loss of 5.39%, corresponding to two free water molecules (calcd 5.85%). Subsequently, the whole framework stated to collapse above the temperature of 250 °C. PXRD is an effective method to investigate the crystalline structure of the synthesized samples. As presented in Figure S2, phase purity could be confirmed by the well-matched diffraction peaks between the as-prepared products and the simulated one.

Considering the pore properties, gas sorption experiments were performed. To obtain dehydrated phase Cd-PTC, as-prepared samples were heated under a vacuum at 80 °C for 5 h to remove all guest H2O molecules. TGA and PXRD patterns of the dehydrated phase further confirmed that the preservation of its crystallinity and the whole framework maintained intact structure (Figures S1 and S2). Nitrogen adsorption/desorption isotherm at 77 K showed the N2 uptake reached 302.4 cm3 g–1 and exhibited a typical type-I curve with an abrupt increase at the beginning (Figure S3), indicating the microporous characteristics. Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) surface area is 965 m2 g–1, while the total pore volume was found to be 0.57 cm3 g–1.

To better evaluate the porosity, different gas sorption curves were taken on, respectively. Obviously, adsorption isotherms of CO2 possess good uptake of 80 cm3 g–1 (273 K) and 58 cm3 g–1(298 K), respectively (a). However, adsorption capacities of N2 and CH4 are quite minimal at the corresponding temperature. Apparently, it displayed a selective adsorption for CO2 over CH4 and N2. This phenomenon could be ascribed to significant CO2 quadrupole moment with a value of −1.4 × 10–39 cm2, generating specific interactions with host frameworks. To better test the sorption selectivity, we applied ideal adsorption solution theory to calculate separation selectivity of CO2 versus N2 or CH4 (volume ratios, 15/85 and 50/50) at ambient pressure up to 100 kPa. As presented in b, the selectivity of CO2/N2 gradually decreased from 175 to 106 (V/V, 15/85). As for CO2/CH4, the selectivity was 31 to 19 (V/V, 50/50). These results indicated that the Cd-PTC framework has strong affinity toward CO2 compared with N2 and CH4.

To further determinate real separation and purification properties, we carried out the dynamic column breakthrough experiments. Thus, mixed gases of CO2/N2 (V/V, 15/85) flowed over a packed bed of Cd-PTC samples at 298 K. Apparently, CO2 could be successfully separated from the mixture with dynamic CO2 uptake of 0.78 mmol g–1, which is compatible to the well-known HKUST-1 (0.45 mmol g–1) and IRMOF-74 (8 mmol g–1). As for CO2/CH4 (V/V, 50/50), at a shorter dimensionless time, the breakthrough could be observed on account of a relatively lower separation ratio of the mixed gases.

According to the previous studies, a large π-conjugated pyrene core could be applied as efficient chromophores to sensitize metal centers through energy transfer, which inspired us to detect the fluorescent properties of Cd-PTC. Therefore, the emission spectra of organic ligand and Cd-PTC were collected at ambient temperature in DMF. As depicted in , Cd-PTC exhibited a broad emission peak at 428 nm (λex = 363 nm). Obviously, a red-shift was observed in comparison with an emission peak of 374 nm for organic ligand, suggesting efficient ligand-to-metal charge transfer. On the other hand, the fluorescent intensity Cd-PTC is stronger than the ligand, indicating that the incorporation of Cd­(II) ion can effectively reduce the energy loss. The enhanced fluorescent properties proved it to be an outstanding candidate for blue fluorescent materials.
cln_elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

H4PTC ligand was obtained through previously reported methods. Reaction of H4PTC with Cd(NO3)2⋅4H2O generated Cd-PTC crystals. The formula was verified through elemental analysis and TGA data to be (Me2NH2)2[Cd(PTC)]⋅2H2O. Structural analysis showed that Cd-PTC crystallized in monoclinic space group C2/c. Each Cd2+ metal center coordinated four bidentate chelating carboxylate groups from four discrete ligands (a), while each PTC4- ligand connected four Cd2+ ions (b), thus forming a novel three-dimensional (3D) anionic MOF along the [100] direction (c). As shown in d,e, this framework possessed 1D rhombic channels with size of 3.5 × 3.6 Å2 along the [001] direction. The calculated solvent accessible volume was 1580.6 Å3 (unit cell volume of 2953.3 Å3), and the porosity was as high as 53.5% by using PLATON. To better understand the intrinsic structure, TOPOS 4.0 program was applied to conduct the topology analysis of Cd-PTC. Each ligand and each Cd2+ ion serve as 4-connected node, respectively, and thus the whole framework could be regarded as binodal (4,4)-connected pts topology with a point symbol of (42⋅84) (f).

Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) of as-prepared Cd-PTC and desolvated Cd-PTC are shown in Figure S1. As-prepared Cd-PTC showed a first weight loss of 5.39%, corresponding to two free water molecules (calcd 5.85%). Subsequently, the whole framework stated to collapse above the temperature of 250 °C. PXRD is an effective method to investigate the crystalline structure of the synthesized samples. As presented in Figure S2, phase purity could be confirmed by the well-matched diffraction peaks between the as-prepared products and the simulated one.

Considering the pore properties, gas sorption experiments were performed. To obtain dehydrated phase Cd-PTC, as-prepared samples were heated under a vacuum at 80 °C for 5 h to remove all guest H2O molecules. TGA and PXRD patterns of the dehydrated phase further confirmed that the preservation of its crystallinity and the whole framework maintained intact structure (Figures S1 and S2). Nitrogen adsorption/desorption isotherm at 77 K showed the N2 uptake reached 302.4 cm3 g-1 and exhibited a typical type-I curve with an abrupt increase at the beginning (Figure S3), indicating the microporous characteristics. Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) surface area is 965 m2 g-1, while the total pore volume was found to be 0.57 cm3 g-1.

To better evaluate the porosity, different gas sorption curves were taken on, respectively. Obviously, adsorption isotherms of CO2 possess good uptake of 80 cm3 g-1 (273 K) and 58 cm3 g-1(298 K), respectively (a). However, adsorption capacities of N2 and CH4 are quite minimal at the corresponding temperature. Apparently, it displayed a selective adsorption for CO2 over CH4 and N2. This phenomenon could be ascribed to significant CO2 quadrupole moment with a value of -1.4 × 10-39 cm2, generating specific interactions with host frameworks. To better test the sorption selectivity, we applied ideal adsorption solution theory to calculate separation selectivity of CO2 versus N2 or CH4 (volume ratios, 15/85 and 50/50) at ambient pressure up to 100 kPa. As presented in b, the selectivity of CO2/N2 gradually decreased from 175 to 106 (V/V, 15/85). As for CO2/CH4, the selectivity was 31 to 19 (V/V, 50/50). These results indicated that the Cd-PTC framework has strong affinity toward CO2 compared with N2 and CH4.

To further determinate real separation and purification properties, we carried out the dynamic column breakthrough experiments. Thus, mixed gases of CO2/N2 (V/V, 15/85) flowed over a packed bed of Cd-PTC samples at 298 K. Apparently, CO2 could be successfully separated from the mixture with dynamic CO2 uptake of 0.78 mmol g-1, which is compatible to the well-known HKUST-1 (0.45 mmol g-1) and IRMOF-74 (8 mmol g-1). As for CO2/CH4 (V/V, 50/50), at a shorter dimensionless time, the breakthrough could be observed on account of a relatively lower separation ratio of the mixed gases.

According to the previous studies, a large π-conjugated pyrene core could be applied as efficient chromophores to sensitize metal centers through energy transfer, which inspired us to detect the fluorescent properties of Cd-PTC. Therefore, the emission spectra of organic ligand and Cd-PTC were collected at ambient temperature in DMF. As depicted in , Cd-PTC exhibited a broad emission peak at 428 nm (λex = 363 nm). Obviously, a red-shift was observed in comparison with an emission peak of 374 nm for organic ligand, suggesting efficient ligand-to-metal charge transfer. On the other hand, the fluorescent intensity Cd-PTC is stronger than the ligand, indicating that the incorporation of Cd(II) ion can effectively reduce the energy loss. The enhanced fluorescent properties proved it to be an outstanding candidate for blue fluorescent materials.

metadata.title:
A Versatile Anionic
Cd(II)-Based Metal–Organic
Framework for CO2 Capture and Nitroaromatic Explosives
Detection
